column2: Introducing VERSO templates to start building interactive stories
column4: You can see the templates live at https://vcsi.cmplxsys.w3.uvm.edu/scrolly-story-1/. The code lives in the following Github repository: https://github.com/Vermont-Complex-Systems/website-template. Vermont Research Open Source Program Office (VERSO) at UVM main website: https://verso.w3.uvm.edu/. Our main website showcasing the science we do at the Vermont Complex Systems Institute: https://complexstories.uvm.edu/. P.S. The amazing story we showcase at first is by Nadieh Bremer: https://endfund.org/visualizing-neglect/.
column5: Introducing VERSO templates to start building interactive stories (2:56)

column2: Building Data Pipelines for Scrollytelling with Dagster
column4: Introduction to ETL data pipelines using Dagster, providing the input to a scrolly story.- The project is live that: https://vcsi.cmplxsys.w3.uvm.edu/geo-story-1/- The code can be found: github.com/jstonge/dag-montreal/
column5: Building Data Pipelines for Scrollytelling with Dagster (21:18)

column2: Building Principled Data Pipelines for Scrollytelling with Maestro
column4: Introduction to principled data processing using Maestro, providing the input to a scrolly story.- The project is live that: https://vcsi.cmplxsys.w3.uvm.edu/geo-story-1/ - The code can be found: https://github.com/jstonge/rdag-montreal/ You can find Nadieh bremer amazing work at https://www.visualcinnamon.com/.
column5: Building Principled Data Pipelines for Scrollytelling with Maestro (22:10)

column2: Scrollytelling with background map using svelte
column4: Following https://youtu.be/coJUJmfrnaQ, we walk through the svelte code to make an interactive scrolly telling story with a background map.
column5: Scrollytelling with background map using svelte (26:11)
